item.title: NHS pay: More health unions join backlash against 1% pay rise
item.description: Health staff "have literally kept the country alive for the past year", says the British Medical Association.

item.title: Pope Francis and top Shia cleric Ali al-Sistani discuss plight of Iraq's Christians
item.description: The Catholic leader has a historic meeting with Iraq's Shia Muslim leader, Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani.

item.title: Dyfed-Powys Police begins investigation into Pembrokeshire firing range death
item.description: A soldier - understood to be in the Welsh Guards - was fatally injured during live-fire training.

item.title: Rhondda: Police probe girl's death after 'disturbing event'
item.description: Two men have been arrested after suffering serious injuries in the incident.

item.title: Downing Street: Millions spent on new media briefing room
item.description: Televised briefings will "increase public accountability and transparency", the Cabinet Office says.

item.title: Covid-19: 'There are people too poor to die'
item.description: In January, the Covid mortality rate in Burnley was more than double the English average.

item.title: Pubs deluged with beer garden bookings
item.description: Pubs in England report high demand bookings from the 12 April opening date for beer gardens.

item.title: Covid-19: Rapid testing available to all businesses in England
item.description: It is hoped the wider rollout of workplace testing will mean more asymptomatic cases are detected.

item.title: John McAfee charged with fraud over cryptocurrency
item.description: The businessman is accused of promoting cryptocurrency to his followers to inflate prices.

item.title: Covid: Helicopter flew from Salford to Preston for sandwich
item.description: A councillor says a pilot's 40-mile trip to get a sandwich is a "flagrant abuse" of lockdown rules.

item.title: The Papers: Easter 'travel permits' and 'slap for carers'
item.description: Many of Saturday's papers also cover the latest teaser from Oprah Winfrey's interview with the Duchess of Sussex.

item.title: Three surprising things you can make with mushrooms
item.description: Fungi are being used to make compostable versions of products, such as coffins and packaging.

item.title: Covid-19: More unions join NHS pay backlash and beer gardens deluged with bookings
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Saturday morning.

item.title: Amanpour: Harry and Meghan Oprah interview 'won't be an easy ride'
item.description: Christiane Amanpour, the chief international anchor of the news channel CNN, was interviewed by Oprah in 2005.

item.title: Week in pictures: 27 February - 5 March 2021
item.description: A selection of powerful images taken around the world this week.

item.title: K2: Noel Hanna 'returning to find climbers' bodies'
item.description: Adventurer Noel Hanna had to abandon a trek last month after five fellow climbers died.

item.title: World's oldest known wild bird has another chick at age of 70
item.description: Wisdom is believed to have had more than 30 chicks in her life so far, and several partners.

item.title: 'I've been listening to 300 vinyl records to get me through lockdown'
item.description: Listening to all her records took Anna Doble back to her youth - releasing memories and emotions.

item.title: Coronavirus: Europe in vaccine race to save summer
item.description: Waiting for a jab and vaccine passport, EU citizens are impatient to get their lives back.

item.title: Myanmar coup: The young rebels risking their lives for the future
item.description: Opponents of Myanmar's military coup face daily threats and violence, and yet defiance continues.

item.title: Why popular YouTubers are building their own sites
item.description: Some big YouTube names are building their own video sites on the side - just in case.

item.title: The mystery American woman wanted in the UK
item.description: Anne Sacoolas faces a US court battle following a road crash that killed British teen Harry Dunn.

item.title: After the dead horse photo, what now for racing?
item.description: The key questions as trainer Gordon Elliott is banned for a year, with six months suspended, amid fallout from the dead horse photo scandal.

item.title: How Kenya's Malindi morphed into 'Little Italy'
item.description: Italian is the lingua franca of Malindi, which can be a culture shock when walking its old Swahili streets.

item.title: England lose India series 3-1 following another abject batting display
item.description: England's series defeat in India is sealed with one final, abject batting collapse on the third day of the fourth Test in Ahmedabad.

item.title: Former ref Probert on handball rule, defending VAR & dreading 'Match of the Day mistake'
item.description: Handball is a minefield, VAR isn't ruining football and top-flight referees are as competent as ever, says former official Lee Probert

item.title: England's Willis could be out for a year after knee surgery
item.description: England and Wasps flanker Jack Willis "could be out for up to a year" after having surgery on a medial collateral ligament injury in his left knee.

item.title: How Gerrard's Rangers can win title this weekend - Scottish Premiership preview
item.description: On a potentially huge weekend at both ends of the table, here's what the Scottish Premiership has in store.

item.title: Grosjean suffered 67G in Bahrain crash as FIA highlights safety improvements
item.description: Romain Grosjean suffered an impact of 67G in his fiery crash at the Bahrain Grand Prix, the official report into the incident concludes.

item.title: What are the new rules for testing and hotel quarantine?
item.description: Travellers going to and from the UK face a growing number of restrictions.

item.title: Covid lockdown: Why Magna Carta won’t exempt you from the rules
item.description: People are turning to tactics that misinterpret outdated law to avoid coronavirus regulations.

item.title: Covid: How will testing work in schools?
item.description: All students in England can return to classrooms from 8 March, but how will Covid testing work?

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford University-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: Postcode look-up: How many vaccinated where you live?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 20 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday in the UK or travel abroad?
item.description: The government has unveiled its plans for unlocking UK restrictions, including holiday travel.

item.title: 'Vaccine passports': Will I need one for going out, work and travel?
item.description: The government is reviewing whether venues can ask for proof of vaccination or a negative test.

item.title: Lockdown Learning: What educational resources are on TV, iPlayer and online?
item.description: As schools remain closed to most pupils, the BBC is offering a wealth of educational material.

item.title: Covid variant: What happens when coronavirus mutates?
item.description: New Covid-19 variants keep appearing – and their mutations are very different to the comic book kind.

item.title: Covid: What’s the problem with the EU vaccine rollout?
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine is being rolled out across the EU but there have been delays.

item.title: Meteor captured on doorbell cameras in England
item.description: A bright streak of light lit up the sky in England shortly before 22:00 GMT on Sunday.

item.title: Covid: Poldark's Richard Harrington took Deliveroo job in lockdown
item.description: Richard Harrington was "thankful to go on my bike every day" as work stopped during the pandemic.

item.title: Bereaved blogger Rochelle Bugg shares story to help young carers
item.description: Rochelle Bugg became a carer at the age of 25 after her mum was diagnosed with a brain tumour.

item.title: Covid in Scotland: Visitors and hugs return to Scottish care homes
item.description: New guidelines allow limited indoor visits, but some care homes are sticking to tougher restrictions.

item.title: Courier driver: 'I was delivering hundreds of parcels a day'
item.description: Courier driver Michael says his volume of parcels has almost doubled since the first lockdown in March.
